author: savid
content:
Off the back of Mikel's [post](https://ethresear.ch/t/bandwidth-availability-in-ethereum-regional-differences-and-network-impacts/21138) for bandwidth availability, I've been looking at the EL side and requesting blob transactions to measure a node's available upload bandwidth.
High level summary of technique:
- Connect to a peer and wait for ~3 0x03 type transaction hashes to be received from peer's mempool
- Request the blob transactions from the peer which can have a payload size anywhere from 100KB to 1MB+
- Measure the time taken from first byte of the RLPx message body to the last and calculate bandwidth

It can be relatively accurate when the peer is close (RLPx is TCP-based) but pretty useless once the target peer gets further away from the source node. I've been testing with nodes in the same data center and between residential ISP nodes in the same city.

**The question is would this data be usable/worthwhile if collected?** It would also be limited to where I could run the source nodes capturing the measurements, as it would only be reasonable to connect to peers within the same city.

author: popef
content: What is the value added when measuring it on the EL side in addition to the CL side?

author: savid
content: mainly an alternate set of data points across the different p2p protocols. There was talk on some CL clients doing some form of limiting on the req/resp domain, but I have not investigated it.
